summary: This is the trust agreement for the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2017 Trust, establishing the trust's terms, trustees, and detailed bequests to numerous individuals upon Epstein's death. It reveals Epstein's extensive financial planning and the network of individuals he intended to benefit. This document is a section of the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2017 Trust agreement, detailing the powers, duties, and compensation of the Trustees, as well as provisions for discretionary distributions, trust administration, and investment authority. It establishes a complex financial structure with significant control granted to the Trustees. This is the 'Jeffrey E. Epstein 2017 Trust', an amended and restated trust agreement establishing a complex trust structure. It details the powers of the trustees, succession plans, and legal provisions designed to shield the trust from oversight and litigation. The document is signed by Epstein and the initial trustees in January 2017.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The creator and primary beneficiary of the trust during his lifetime, reserving extensive control over the trust assets and making numerous bequests.

persons.name: Eva Andersson Dubin
persons.context: Named as one of the three initial trustees of the trust and a contingent beneficiary who would receive the residuary estate if the primary residuary beneficiary predeceased her.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.context: One of the initial trustees appointed to manage the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2017 Trust, as indicated by his signature (listed as 'K. Indyke' in one place and 'Darren K. Indyke' in another).

persons.name: Richard D. Kahn
persons.context: Named as one of the three initial trustees. He is also a significant beneficiary, slated to receive $10 million and have his debts to Epstein's entities forgiven.

persons.name: Karyna Shuliak
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $10 million plus a $10 million annuity, and have any loans from Epstein forgiven.

persons.name: Michelle Fern Saipher
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $3 million, contingent on being married to Darren Indyke at Epstein's death, for the purpose of terminating a specific real estate contract.

persons.name: Lesley Katherine Groff
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $2 million and have any loans from Epstein forgiven.

persons.name: Lawrence Paul Visoski, Jr.
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $2 million and have any loans from Epstein forgiven.

persons.name: Luciano A. Fontanilla, Jr.
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive an annuity, a specific property in Valley Stream, NY, and have any loans from Epstein forgiven.

persons.name: Ann Rodriguez
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $500,000.

persons.name: Valdson Viera Contrin
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $500,000.

persons.name: Merwin Dela Cruz
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $100,000.

persons.name: Janusz Banasiak
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $25,000.

persons.name: Brice Gordon
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $200,000, contingent on continuing to provide property-related services for two years after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Bella Klein
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $250,000.

persons.name: David Rogers
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $500,000.

persons.name: Steve Chavez
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $66,000.

persons.name: Cynthia Cano
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $35,000.

persons.name: Carlos Delgado
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $42,000.

persons.name: Lisa Kahn
persons.context: Mentioned as the spouse of Richard Kahn in the context of debt forgiveness provisions for entities beneficially owned by them.

persons.name: Rosalyn V. Fontanilla
persons.context: Mentioned as the spouse of Luciano Fontanilla, Jr., whose children would be contingent beneficiaries of his annuity.

persons.name: Kathryn Ruemmler
persons.context: Named as the first successor trustee to be appointed if a trustee resigns, is removed, or becomes incapacitated.

persons.name: Stephen Hanson
persons.context: Named as the second successor trustee to be appointed to fill vacancies, ensuring the trust always has three acting trustees.

persons.name: Lesley K Groff
persons.context: The notary public who witnessed and notarized the signatures of Jeffrey Epstein and several trustees on the document.

connections.description: Epstein names Indyke as a trustee and a major beneficiary, and the document references Indyke's financial obligations to Epstein's entities.
Epstein names Kahn as a trustee and a major beneficiary, and the document references Kahn's financial obligations to Epstein's entities.
Epstein names Dubin as a trustee and the contingent beneficiary of the residuary estate and a specific residence trust.
Saipher's bequest is contingent on her being married to Indyke at the time of Epstein's death.
Lisa Kahn is mentioned as Richard Kahn's spouse in the context of debt forgiveness for entities they beneficially own.
Rosalyn is mentioned as the spouse of Luciano, and their children are named as contingent beneficiaries of his annuity.
Epstein designates Shuliak as a major beneficiary, set to receive $20 million in total value and have loans forgiven.
Epstein appointed Dubin as an initial trustee of his 2017 trust, granting her fiduciary authority over his assets.
Epstein appointed Kahn as an initial trustee of his 2017 trust, granting him fiduciary authority over his assets.
Epstein appointed Indyke as an initial trustee of his 2017 trust, granting him fiduciary authority over his assets.
Both served as initial trustees of the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2017 Trust, sharing fiduciary responsibilities.
Ruemmler is designated as the first successor trustee, and Hanson is designated to fill subsequent vacancies, establishing a planned succession order for the trust.

events.title: Creation of Jeffrey E. Epstein 2017 Trust
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein establishes a revocable trust, naming Eva Andersson Dubin, Darren K. Indyke, and Richard D. Kahn as trustees and outlining extensive bequests to numerous individuals.

events.title: Execution of Epstein 2017 Trust
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein and the initial trustees sign the Amended and Restated Trust Agreement, formally establishing the trust.

locations: 18 Teneyck Avenue, Valley Stream, New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein established a revocable trust in January 2017, reserving the right to amend, revoke, or withdraw assets at any time during his life.
The trust names Eva Andersson Dubin, Darren K. Indyke, and Richard D. Kahn as the initial trustees.

The document lists 28 specific bequests to individuals, including multi-million dollar payments and annuities to associates like Karyna Shuliak ($20M total), Darren Indyke ($10M), Richard Kahn ($10M), and staff like Lesley Groff and Lawrence Visoski.

Epstein's ultimate residuary beneficiary, after a primary individual (name redacted) and contingent beneficiary Eva Dubin, is the Board of Trustees of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), to establish 'The Jeffrey E. Epstein Fund' for student financial aid.
The trust includes provisions to forgive loans made to numerous individuals and entities, and to repay debts owed to Epstein by trustees Indyke and Kahn from the trust assets.

The trust agreement grants Trustees extremely broad discretionary powers to manage assets without judicial oversight, including the power to invest in virtually any asset class and conduct business operations.
Trustees are entitled to an annual compensation of $250,000 each, in addition to any bequests under the trust terms, and are reimbursed for all reasonable expenses.
The trust includes a strong spendthrift provision protecting trust assets from the beneficiaries' creditors until distributions are actually made.
The trust is governed by the United States Virgin Islands Rule Against Perpetuities, indicating it was likely established under Virgin Islands law.
The document outlines specific prohibitions against self-dealing, preventing Trustees from buying/selling trust property to/from themselves, their relatives, or business associates.
Jeffrey Epstein established a complex trust in January 2017, naming Eva Andersson Dubin, Richard D. Kahn, and Darren K. Indyke as initial trustees.
The trust agreement includes strong exculpation and indemnification clauses, shielding trustees from liability unless they act in 'bad faith' and requiring the trust to pay their legal defense costs.

The trust is governed by the laws of the U.S. Virgin Islands, a jurisdiction chosen for its favorable trust laws, and includes provisions to relieve trustees from standard statutory filing and accounting requirements.
The document contains a 'no contest' clause that disinherits any beneficiary who challenges the validity of the trust or Epstein's will.
The trustees are granted broad powers, including the discretion to transfer the trust's legal 'situs' (location) to another country or jurisdiction without court approval.
